text: The Theaetetus is one of the narrated dialogues of Plato, and is

author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

text: Theaetetus, the hero of the battle of Corinth and of the dialogue, is
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

text: a "facon de parler," by which he imposed on the common herd like you and
title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

text: doctrine, not of Protagoras only, but of all philosophers, with the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

text: words--
title: Theaetetus

text: "Ocean, whence the gods sprang, and mother Tethys."
title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: to move, "chaos would come again." Now apply this doctrine of "All
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

text: answer.'
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: mind, as Euripides would say?' 'True.' 'The thoroughbred Sophists, who
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: our ideas are clear and consistent. And we cannot be wrong in saying,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: first, that nothing can be greater or less while remaining equal;
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: dice, and with similar examples?--that is the question.' 'I am often
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

text: fix them. Are not these speculations charming, Theaetetus, and very good
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

text: notion that "All things are becoming"?'
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: 'When I hear your arguments, I am marvellously ready to assent.'
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: 'But I ought not to conceal from you that there is a serious objection
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: which may be urged against this doctrine of Protagoras. For there are
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: we are not dreaming? Even the fancies of madmen are real at the time.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and the false in such cases? Having stated the objection, I will now
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: active or passive has a different power. There are infinite agents and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: patients in the world, and these produce in every combination of them a
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: or he may be well,--and remember that Socrates, with all his accidents,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: is spoken of. The wine which I drink when I am well is pleasant to
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: me, but the same wine is unpleasant to me when I am ill. And there
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: is nothing else from which I can receive the same impression, nor can
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: another receive the same impression from the wine. Neither can I and the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: in becoming is relative to the other, but they have no other relation;
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: put the question in a new form. He proceeds as follows:--'Should we say
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: 'Excellent; I want you to grow, and therefore I will leave that answer

author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: remember?' 'He does.' 'Then he may remember and not see; and if seeing
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: perhaps we are crowing too soon; and if Protagoras, "the father of the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: myth," had been alive, the result might have been very different. But he
title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

text: been very zealous in defending him.'
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

text: resuming the attack. He asks whether a man can know and not know at the
title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: He asks whether you can know near and not at a distance; whether you can
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: have a sharp and also a dull knowledge. While you are wondering at his
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: incomparable wisdom, he gets you into his power, and you will not escape
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: until you have come to an understanding with him about the money which
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: contemptuously replying that he is not responsible for the admissions
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: that the memory of a feeling is the same as a feeling, or denied that a
title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: will have extreme precision, I say that man in different relations is
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: appears to him is not what is. As to your pigs and baboons, you are
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: yourself a pig, and you make my writings a sport of other swine. But
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: I still affirm that man is the measure of all things, although I admit
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: superior knowledge. For the impressions of the sick are as true as the
title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: can any man be cured of a false opinion, for there is no such thing;

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: opinion. This is effected in the body by the drugs of the physician, and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: is not truer, but only better than the old. And philosophers are not
title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: to a state), and in return, they deserve to be well paid. And you,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Socrates, whether you please or not, must continue to be a measure.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: This is my defence, and I must request you to meet me fairly. We are
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: professing to reason, and not merely to dispute; and there is a great
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: trying to understand him and to point out his errors to him, whether
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: arising from his own or from his companion's fault; he does not argue
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: from the customary use of names, which the vulgar pervert in all manner
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of ways. If you are gentle to an adversary he will follow and love you;
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Socrates, to adopt this humaner method, and to avoid captious and verbal
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: criticisms.'

author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: we do not know; nor can we think that which we do not know to be that
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: which we know, or that which we know to be that which we do not know.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: And what other case is conceivable, upon the supposition that we either
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: know or do not know all things? Let us try another answer in the sphere
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of being: 'When a man thinks, and thinks that which is not.' But would
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: this hold in any parallel case? Can a man see and see nothing? or hear
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and hear nothing? or touch and touch nothing? Must he not see, hear, or
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: touch some one existing thing? For if he thinks about nothing he does
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: not think, and not thinking he cannot think falsely. And so the path of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: being is closed against us, as well as the path of knowledge. But may
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: there not be 'heterodoxy,' or transference of opinion;--I mean, may not
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: one thing be supposed to be another? Theaetetus is confident that this
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: must be 'the true falsehood,' when a man puts good for evil or evil
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: for good. Socrates will not discourage him by attacking the paradoxical
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: expression 'true falsehood,' but passes on. The new notion involves a
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: process of thinking about two things, either together or alternately.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: And thinking is the conversing of the mind with herself, which is
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: carried on in question and answer, until she no longer doubts, but
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: determines and forms an opinion. And false opinion consists in saying to
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: yourself, that one thing is another. But did you ever say to yourself,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: that good is evil, or evil good? Even in sleep, did you ever imagine
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: that odd was even? Or did any man in his senses ever fancy that an ox
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: was a horse, or that two are one? So that we can never think one thing
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: to be another; for you must not meet me with the verbal quibble that
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: one--eteron--is other--eteron (both 'one' and 'other' in Greek are
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: called 'other'--eteron). He who has both the two things in his mind,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: cannot misplace them; and he who has only one of them in his mind,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: cannot misplace them--on either supposition transplacement is
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: inconceivable.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: But perhaps there may still be a sense in which we can think that
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: which we do not know to be that which we know: e.g. Theaetetus may know
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Socrates, but at a distance he may mistake another person for him. This
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: process may be conceived by the help of an image. Let us suppose that
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: every man has in his mind a block of wax of various qualities, the gift
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of Memory, the mother of the Muses; and on this he receives the seal or
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: stamp of those sensations and perceptions which he wishes to remember.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: That which he succeeds in stamping is remembered and known by him as
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: long as the impression lasts; but that, of which the impression is
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: rubbed out or imperfectly made, is forgotten, and not known. No one can
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: think one thing to be another, when he has the memorial or seal of both
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of these in his soul, and a sensible impression of neither; or when he
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: knows one and does not know the other, and has no memorial or seal of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the other; or when he knows neither; or when he perceives both, or one
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and not the other, or neither; or when he perceives and knows both,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and identifies what he perceives with what he knows (this is still more
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: impossible); or when he does not know one, and does not know and does
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: not perceive the other; or does not perceive one, and does not know
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and does not perceive the other; or has no perception or knowledge
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of either--all these cases must be excluded. But he may err when he
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: confuses what he knows or perceives, or what he perceives and does not
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: know, with what he knows, or what he knows and perceives with what he
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: knows and perceives.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Theaetetus is unable to follow these distinctions; which Socrates
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: proceeds to illustrate by examples, first of all remarking, that
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: knowledge may exist without perception, and perception without
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: knowledge. I may know Theodorus and Theaetetus and not see them; I
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: may see them, and not know them. 'That I understand.' But I could not
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: mistake one for the other if I knew you both, and had no perception of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: either; or if I knew one only, and perceived neither; or if I knew
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and perceived neither, or in any other of the excluded cases. The only
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: possibility of error is: 1st, when knowing you and Theodorus, and having
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the impression of both of you on the waxen block, I, seeing you both
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: imperfectly and at a distance, put the foot in the wrong shoe--that
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: is to say, put the seal or stamp on the wrong object: or 2ndly, when
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: knowing both of you I only see one; or when, seeing and knowing you
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: both, I fail to identify the impression and the object. But there could
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: be no error when perception and knowledge correspond.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: The waxen block in the heart of a man's soul, as I may say in the words
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of Homer, who played upon the words ker and keros, may be smooth and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: deep, and large enough, and then the signs are clearly marked and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: lasting, and do not get confused. But in the 'hairy heart,' as the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: all-wise poet sings, when the wax is muddy or hard or moist, there is
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: a corresponding confusion and want of retentiveness; in the muddy and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: impure there is indistinctness, and still more in the hard, for there
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the impressions have no depth of wax, and in the moist they are too
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: soon effaced. Yet greater is the indistinctness when they are all jolted
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: together in a little soul, which is narrow and has no room. These are
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the sort of natures which have false opinion; from stupidity they see
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and hear and think amiss; and this is falsehood and ignorance. Error,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: then, is a confusion of thought and sense.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Theaetetus is delighted with this explanation. But Socrates has no
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: sooner found the new solution than he sinks into a fit of despondency.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: For an objection occurs to him:--May there not be errors where there is
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: no confusion of mind and sense? e.g. in numbers. No one can confuse
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the man whom he has in his thoughts with the horse which he has in his
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: thoughts, but he may err in the addition of five and seven. And observe
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: that these are purely mental conceptions. Thus we are involved once more
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: in the dilemma of saying, either that there is no such thing as false
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: opinion, or that a man knows what he does not know.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: We are at our wit's end, and may therefore be excused for making a
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: bold diversion. All this time we have been repeating the words 'know,'
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: 'understand,' yet we do not know what knowledge is. 'Why, Socrates,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: how can you argue at all without using them?' Nay, but the true hero
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of dialectic would have forbidden me to use them until I had explained
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: them. And I must explain them now. The verb 'to know' has two senses,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: to have and to possess knowledge, and I distinguish 'having' from
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: 'possessing.' A man may possess a garment which he does not wear; or he
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: may have wild birds in an aviary; these in one sense he possesses, and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: in another he has none of them. Let this aviary be an image of the mind,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: as the waxen block was; when we are young, the aviary is empty; after
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: a time the birds are put in; for under this figure we may describe
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: different forms of knowledge;--there are some of them in groups, and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: some single, which are flying about everywhere; and let us suppose
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: a hunt after the science of odd and even, or some other science. The
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: possession of the birds is clearly not the same as the having them in
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the hand. And the original chase of them is not the same as taking them
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: in the hand when they are already caged.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: This distinction between use and possession saves us from the absurdity
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of supposing that we do not know what we know, because we may know in
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: one sense, i.e. possess, what we do not know in another, i.e. use. But
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: have we not escaped one difficulty only to encounter a greater? For how
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: can the exchange of two kinds of knowledge ever become false opinion?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: As well might we suppose that ignorance could make a man know, or that
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: blindness could make him see. Theaetetus suggests that in the aviary
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: there may be flying about mock birds, or forms of ignorance, and we
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: put forth our hands and grasp ignorance, when we are intending to grasp
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: knowledge. But how can he who knows the forms of knowledge and the forms
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of ignorance imagine one to be the other? Is there some other form of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: knowledge which distinguishes them? and another, and another? Thus we go
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: round and round in a circle and make no progress.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: All this confusion arises out of our attempt to explain false opinion
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: without having explained knowledge. What then is knowledge? Theaetetus
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: repeats that knowledge is true opinion. But this seems to be refuted by
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the instance of orators and judges. For surely the orator cannot convey
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: a true knowledge of crimes at which the judges were not present; he
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: can only persuade them, and the judge may form a true opinion and truly
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: judge. But if true opinion were knowledge they could not have judged
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: without knowledge.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Once more. Theaetetus offers a definition which he has heard: Knowledge
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: is true opinion accompanied by definition or explanation. Socrates has
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: had a similar dream, and has further heard that the first elements are
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: names only, and that definition or explanation begins when they are
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: combined; the letters are unknown, the syllables or combinations
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: are known. But this new hypothesis when tested by the letters of the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: alphabet is found to break down. The first syllable of Socrates' name
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: is SO. But what is SO? Two letters, S and O, a sibilant and a vowel,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of which no further explanation can be given. And how can any one
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: be ignorant of either of them, and yet know both of them? There is,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: however, another alternative:--We may suppose that the syllable has a
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: separate form or idea distinct from the letters or parts. The all of the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: parts may not be the whole. Theaetetus is very much inclined to adopt
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: this suggestion, but when interrogated by Socrates he is unable to
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: draw any distinction between the whole and all the parts. And if the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: syllables have no parts, then they are those original elements of which
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: there is no explanation. But how can the syllable be known if the letter
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: remains unknown? In learning to read as children, we are first taught
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the letters and then the syllables. And in music, the notes, which
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: are the letters, have a much more distinct meaning to us than the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: combination of them.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Once more, then, we must ask the meaning of the statement, that
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: 'Knowledge is right opinion, accompanied by explanation or definition.'
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Explanation may mean, (1) the reflection or expression of a man's
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: thoughts--but every man who is not deaf and dumb is able to express his
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: thoughts--or (2) the enumeration of the elements of which anything is
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: composed. A man may have a true opinion about a waggon, but then, and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: then only, has he knowledge of a waggon when he is able to enumerate
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the hundred planks of Hesiod. Or he may know the syllables of the name
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Theaetetus, but not the letters; yet not until he knows both can he be
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: said to have knowledge as well as opinion. But on the other hand he may
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: know the syllable 'The' in the name Theaetetus, yet he may be mistaken
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: about the same syllable in the name Theodorus, and in learning to read
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: we often make such mistakes. And even if he could write out all the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: letters and syllables of your name in order, still he would only have
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: right opinion. Yet there may be a third meaning of the definition,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: besides the image or expression of the mind, and the enumeration of the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: elements, viz. (3) perception of difference.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: For example, I may see a man who has eyes, nose, and mouth;--that will
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: not distinguish him from any other man. Or he may have a snub-nose and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: prominent eyes;--that will not distinguish him from myself and you and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: others who are like me. But when I see a certain kind of snub-nosedness,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: then I recognize Theaetetus. And having this sign of difference, I have
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: knowledge. But have I knowledge or opinion of this difference; if I
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: have only opinion I have not knowledge; if I have knowledge we assume
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: a disputed term; for knowledge will have to be defined as right opinion
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: with knowledge of difference.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: And so, Theaetetus, knowledge is neither perception nor true opinion,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: nor yet definition accompanying true opinion. And I have shown that the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: children of your brain are not worth rearing. Are you still in labour,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: or have you brought all you have to say about knowledge to the birth? If
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: you have any more thoughts, you will be the better for having got rid of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: these; or if you have none, you will be the better for not fancying that
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: you know what you do not know. Observe the limits of my art, which, like
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: my mother's, is an art of midwifery; I do not pretend to compare with
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the good and wise of this and other ages.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: And now I go to meet Meletus at the porch of the King Archon; but
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: to-morrow I shall hope to see you again, Theodorus, at this place.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: I. The saying of Theaetetus, that 'Knowledge is sensible perception,'
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: may be assumed to be a current philosophical opinion of the age. 'The
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: ancients,' as Aristotle (De Anim.) says, citing a verse of Empedocles,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: 'affirmed knowledge to be the same as perception.' We may now examine
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: these words, first, with reference to their place in the history of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: philosophy, and secondly, in relation to modern speculations.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: (a) In the age of Socrates the mind was passing from the object to the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: subject. The same impulse which a century before had led men to form
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: conceptions of the world, now led them to frame general notions of the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: human faculties and feelings, such as memory, opinion, and the like. The
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: simplest of these is sensation, or sensible perception, by which Plato
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: seems to mean the generalized notion of feelings and impressions of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: sense, without determining whether they are conscious or not.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: The theory that 'Knowledge is sensible perception' is the antithesis of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: that which derives knowledge from the mind (Theaet.), or which assumes
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the existence of ideas independent of the mind (Parm.). Yet from their
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: extreme abstraction these theories do not represent the opposite poles
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of thought in the same way that the corresponding differences would
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: in modern philosophy. The most ideal and the most sensational have a
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: tendency to pass into one another; Heracleitus, like his great successor
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Hegel, has both aspects. The Eleatic isolation of Being and the Megarian
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: or Cynic isolation of individuals are placed in the same class by Plato
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: (Soph.); and the same principle which is the symbol of motion to one
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: mind is the symbol of rest to another. The Atomists, who are sometimes
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: regarded as the Materialists of Plato, denied the reality of sensation.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: And in the ancient as well as the modern world there were reactions from
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: theory to experience, from ideas to sense. This is a point of view from
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: which the philosophy of sensation presented great attraction to the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: ancient thinker. Amid the conflict of ideas and the variety of opinions,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the impression of sense remained certain and uniform. Hardness,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: softness, cold, heat, etc. are not absolutely the same to different
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: persons, but the art of measuring could at any rate reduce them all
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: to definite natures (Republic). Thus the doctrine that knowledge is
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: perception supplies or seems to supply a firm standing ground. Like the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: other notions of the earlier Greek philosophy, it was held in a very
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: simple way, without much basis of reasoning, and without suggesting the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: questions which naturally arise in our own minds on the same subject.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: (b) The fixedness of impressions of sense furnishes a link of connexion
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: between ancient and modern philosophy. The modern thinker often repeats
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the parallel axiom, 'All knowledge is experience.' He means to say that
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the outward and not the inward is both the original source and the final
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: criterion of truth, because the outward can be observed and analyzed;
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the inward is only known by external results, and is dimly perceived
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: by each man for himself. In what does this differ from the saying of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Theaetetus? Chiefly in this--that the modern term 'experience,' while
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: implying a point of departure in sense and a return to sense, also
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: includes all the processes of reasoning and imagination which have
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: intervened. The necessary connexion between them by no means affords a
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: measure of the relative degree of importance which is to be ascribed to
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: either element. For the inductive portion of any science may be small,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: as in mathematics or ethics, compared with that which the mind has
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: attained by reasoning and reflection on a very few facts.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: II. The saying that 'All knowledge is sensation' is identified by Plato
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: with the Protagorean thesis that 'Man is the measure of all things.'
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: The interpretation which Protagoras himself is supposed to give of these
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: latter words is: 'Things are to me as they appear to me, and to you as
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: they appear to you.' But there remains still an ambiguity both in the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: text and in the explanation, which has to be cleared up. Did Protagoras
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: merely mean to assert the relativity of knowledge to the human mind? Or
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: did he mean to deny that there is an objective standard of truth?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: These two questions have not been always clearly distinguished; the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: relativity of knowledge has been sometimes confounded with uncertainty.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: The untutored mind is apt to suppose that objects exist independently
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of the human faculties, because they really exist independently of the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: faculties of any individual. In the same way, knowledge appears to be
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: a body of truths stored up in books, which when once ascertained are
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: independent of the discoverer. Further consideration shows us that these
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: truths are not really independent of the mind; there is an adaptation of

text: the sense, and the sense would have no power of distinguishing without
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the mind.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: But prior to objects of sense there is a third nature in which they
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: are contained--that is to say, space, which may be explained in various
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: ways. It is the element which surrounds them; it is the vacuum or void
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: which they leave or occupy when passing from one portion of space to
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: another. It might be described in the language of ancient philosophy, as
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: 'the Not-being' of objects. It is a negative idea which in the course
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of ages has become positive. It is originally derived from the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: contemplation of the world without us--the boundless earth or sea, the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: vacant heaven, and is therefore acquired chiefly through the sense of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: sight: to the blind the conception of space is feeble and inadequate,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: derived for the most part from touch or from the descriptions of others.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: At first it appears to be continuous; afterwards we perceive it to be
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: capable of division by lines or points, real or imaginary. By the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: help of mathematics we form another idea of space, which is altogether
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: independent of experience. Geometry teaches us that the innumerable
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: lines and figures by which space is or may be intersected are absolutely
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: true in all their combinations and consequences. New and unchangeable
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: properties of space are thus developed, which are proved to us in a
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: thousand ways by mathematical reasoning as well as by common experience.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Through quantity and measure we are conducted to our simplest and purest
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: notion of matter, which is to the cube or solid what space is to
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the square or surface. And all our applications of mathematics are
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: applications of our ideas of space to matter. No wonder then that they
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: seem to have a necessary existence to us. Being the simplest of our
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: ideas, space is also the one of which we have the most difficulty in
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: ridding ourselves. Neither can we set a limit to it, for wherever we
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: fix a limit, space is springing up beyond. Neither can we conceive a
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: smallest or indivisible portion of it; for within the smallest there
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: is a smaller still; and even these inconceivable qualities of space,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: whether the infinite or the infinitesimal, may be made the subject of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: reasoning and have a certain truth to us.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Whether space exists in the mind or out of it, is a question which has
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: no meaning. We should rather say that without it the mind is incapable
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of conceiving the body, and therefore of conceiving itself. The mind may
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: be indeed imagined to contain the body, in the same way that Aristotle
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: (partly following Plato) supposes God to be the outer heaven or circle
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of the universe. But how can the individual mind carry about the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: universe of space packed up within, or how can separate minds have
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: either a universe of their own or a common universe? In such conceptions
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: there seems to be a confusion of the individual and the universal. To
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: say that we can only have a true idea of ourselves when we deny the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: reality of that by which we have any idea of ourselves is an absurdity.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: The earth which is our habitation and 'the starry heaven above' and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: we ourselves are equally an illusion, if space is only a quality or
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: condition of our minds.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Again, we may compare the truths of space with other truths derived from
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: experience, which seem to have a necessity to us in proportion to the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: frequency of their recurrence or the truth of the consequences which may
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: be inferred from them. We are thus led to remark that the necessity
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: in our ideas of space on which much stress has been laid, differs in a
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: slight degree only from the necessity which appears to belong to other
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of our ideas, e.g. weight, motion, and the like. And there is another
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: way in which this necessity may be explained. We have been taught it,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and the truth which we were taught or which we inherited has never been
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: contradicted in all our experience and is therefore confirmed by it. Who
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: can resist an idea which is presented to him in a general form in every
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: moment of his life and of which he finds no instance to the contrary?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: The greater part of what is sometimes regarded as the a priori intuition
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of space is really the conception of the various geometrical figures of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: which the properties have been revealed by mathematical analysis. And
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the certainty of these properties is immeasurably increased to us by our
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: finding that they hold good not only in every instance, but in all the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: consequences which are supposed to flow from them.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Neither must we forget that our idea of space, like our other ideas,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: has a history. The Homeric poems contain no word for it; even the later
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Greek philosophy has not the Kantian notion of space, but only the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: definite 'place' or 'the infinite.' To Plato, in the Timaeus, it is
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: known only as the 'nurse of generation.' When therefore we speak of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the necessity of our ideas of space we must remember that this is a
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: necessity which has grown up with the growth of the human mind, and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: has been made by ourselves. We can free ourselves from the perplexities
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: which are involved in it by ascending to a time in which they did not
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: as yet exist. And when space or time are described as 'a priori forms or
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: intuitions added to the matter given in sensation,' we should consider
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: that such expressions belong really to the 'pre-historic study' of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: philosophy, i.e. to the eighteenth century, when men sought to explain
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the human mind without regard to history or language or the social
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: nature of man.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: In every act of sense there is a latent perception of space, of which
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: we only become conscious when objects are withdrawn from it. There are
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: various ways in which we may trace the connexion between them. We may
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: think of space as unresisting matter, and of matter as divided into
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: objects; or of objects again as formed by abstraction into a collective
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: notion of matter, and of matter as rarefied into space. And motion may
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: be conceived as the union of there and not there in space, and force
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: as the materializing or solidification of motion. Space again is the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: individual and universal in one; or, in other words, a perception and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: also a conception. So easily do what are sometimes called our simple
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: ideas pass into one another, and differences of kind resolve themselves
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: into differences of degree.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Within or behind space there is another abstraction in many respects
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: similar to it--time, the form of the inward, as space is the form of the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: outward. As we cannot think of outward objects of sense or of outward
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: sensations without space, so neither can we think of a succession of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: sensations without time. It is the vacancy of thoughts or sensations,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: as space is the void of outward objects, and we can no more imagine
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the mind without the one than the world without the other. It is to
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: arithmetic what space is to geometry; or, more strictly, arithmetic may
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: be said to be equally applicable to both. It is defined in our minds,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: partly by the analogy of space and partly by the recollection of events
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: which have happened to us, or the consciousness of feelings which we are
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: experiencing. Like space, it is without limit, for whatever beginning or
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: end of time we fix, there is a beginning and end before them, and so
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: on without end. We speak of a past, present, and future, and again the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: analogy of space assists us in conceiving of them as coexistent. When
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the limit of time is removed there arises in our minds the idea of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: eternity, which at first, like time itself, is only negative, but
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: gradually, when connected with the world and the divine nature, like
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the other negative infinity of space, becomes positive. Whether time is
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: prior to the mind and to experience, or coeval with them, is (like
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the parallel question about space) unmeaning. Like space it has been
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: realized gradually: in the Homeric poems, or even in the Hesiodic
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: cosmogony, there is no more notion of time than of space. The conception
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of being is more general than either, and might therefore with greater
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: plausibility be affirmed to be a condition or quality of the mind. The a
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: priori intuitions of Kant would have been as unintelligible to Plato as
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: his a priori synthetical propositions to Aristotle. The philosopher of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Konigsberg supposed himself to be analyzing a necessary mode of thought:
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: he was not aware that he was dealing with a mere abstraction. But now
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: that we are able to trace the gradual developement of ideas through
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: religion, through language, through abstractions, why should we
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: interpose the fiction of time between ourselves and realities? Why
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: should we single out one of these abstractions to be the a priori
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: condition of all the others? It comes last and not first in the order of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: our thoughts, and is not the condition precedent of them, but the last
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: generalization of them. Nor can any principle be imagined more suicidal
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: to philosophy than to assume that all the truth which we are capable of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: attaining is seen only through an unreal medium. If all that exists
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: in time is illusion, we may well ask with Plato, 'What becomes of the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: mind?'
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Leaving the a priori conditions of sensation we may proceed to consider
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: acts of sense. These admit of various degrees of duration or intensity;
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: they admit also of a greater or less extension from one object, which is
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: perceived directly, to many which are perceived indirectly or in a less
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: degree, and to the various associations of the object which are latent
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: in the mind. In general the greater the intension the less the extension
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of them. The simplest sensation implies some relation of objects to
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: one another, some position in space, some relation to a previous or
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: subsequent sensation. The acts of seeing and hearing may be almost
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: unconscious and may pass away unnoted; they may also leave an impression
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: behind them or power of recalling them. If, after seeing an object we
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: shut our eyes, the object remains dimly seen in the same or about the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: same place, but with form and lineaments half filled up. This is the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: simplest act of memory. And as we cannot see one thing without at
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the same time seeing another, different objects hang together in
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: recollection, and when we call for one the other quickly follows. To
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: think of the place in which we have last seen a thing is often the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: best way of recalling it to the mind. Hence memory is dependent on
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: association. The act of recollection may be compared to the sight of an
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: object at a great distance which we have previously seen near and seek
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: to bring near to us in thought. Memory is to sense as dreaming is to
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: waking; and like dreaming has a wayward and uncertain power of recalling
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: impressions from the past.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Thus begins the passage from the outward to the inward sense. But as
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: yet there is no conception of a universal--the mind only remembers
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the individual object or objects, and is always attaching to them some
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: colour or association of sense. The power of recollection seems to
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: depend on the intensity or largeness of the perception, or on the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: strength of some emotion with which it is inseparably connected. This is
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the natural memory which is allied to sense, such as children appear to
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: have and barbarians and animals. It is necessarily limited in range, and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: its limitation is its strength. In later life, when the mind has become
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: crowded with names, acts, feelings, images innumerable, we acquire
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: by education another memory of system and arrangement which is both
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: stronger and weaker than the first--weaker in the recollection
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of sensible impressions as they are represented to us by eye or
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: ear--stronger by the natural connexion of ideas with objects or with one
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: another. And many of the notions which form a part of the train of our
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: thoughts are hardly realized by us at the time, but, like numbers or
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: algebraical symbols, are used as signs only, thus lightening the labour
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of recollection.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: And now we may suppose that numerous images present themselves to the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: mind, which begins to act upon them and to arrange them in various
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: ways. Besides the impression of external objects present with us or just
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: absent from us, we have a dimmer conception of other objects which have
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: disappeared from our immediate recollection and yet continue to exist in
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: us. The mind is full of fancies which are passing to and fro before it.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Some feeling or association calls them up, and they are uttered by the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: lips. This is the first rudimentary imagination, which may be truly
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: described in the language of Hobbes, as 'decaying sense,' an expression
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: which may be applied with equal truth to memory as well. For memory and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: imagination, though we sometimes oppose them, are nearly allied; the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: difference between them seems chiefly to lie in the activity of the one
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: compared with the passivity of the other. The sense decaying in memory
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: receives a flash of light or life from imagination. Dreaming is a link
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of connexion between them; for in dreaming we feebly recollect and also
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: feebly imagine at one and the same time. When reason is asleep the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: lower part of the mind wanders at will amid the images which have been
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: received from without, the intelligent element retires, and the sensual
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: or sensuous takes its place. And so in the first efforts of imagination
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: reason is latent or set aside; and images, in part disorderly, but also
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: having a unity (however imperfect) of their own, pour like a flood over
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the mind. And if we could penetrate into the heads of animals we should
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: probably find that their intelligence, or the state of what in them is
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: analogous to our intelligence, is of this nature.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Thus far we have been speaking of men, rather in the points in which
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: they resemble animals than in the points in which they differ from
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: them. The animal too has memory in various degrees, and the elements
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of imagination, if, as appears to be the case, he dreams. How far their
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: powers or instincts are educated by the circumstances of their lives
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: or by intercourse with one another or with mankind, we cannot precisely
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: tell. They, like ourselves, have the physical inheritance of form,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: scent, hearing, sight, and other qualities or instincts. But they
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: have not the mental inheritance of thoughts and ideas handed down by
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: tradition, 'the slow additions that build up the mind' of the human
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: race. And language, which is the great educator of mankind, is wanting
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: in them; whereas in us language is ever present--even in the infant the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: latent power of naming is almost immediately observable. And therefore
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the description which has been already given of the nascent power of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the faculties is in reality an anticipation. For simultaneous with their
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: growth in man a growth of language must be supposed. The child of two
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: years old sees the fire once and again, and the feeble observation of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the same recurring object is associated with the feeble utterance of the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: name by which he is taught to call it. Soon he learns to utter the name
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: when the object is no longer there, but the desire or imagination of it
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: is present to him. At first in every use of the word there is a colour
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of sense, an indistinct picture of the object which accompanies it. But
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: in later years he sees in the name only the universal or class word, and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the more abstract the notion becomes, the more vacant is the image
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: which is presented to him. Henceforward all the operations of his mind,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: including the perceptions of sense, are a synthesis of sensations,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: words, conceptions. In seeing or hearing or looking or listening the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: sensible impression prevails over the conception and the word. In
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: reflection the process is reversed--the outward object fades away into
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: nothingness, the name or the conception or both together are everything.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Language, like number, is intermediate between the two, partaking of the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: definiteness of the outer and of the universality of the inner world.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: For logic teaches us that every word is really a universal, and only
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: condescends by the help of position or circumlocution to become the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: expression of individuals or particulars. And sometimes by using words
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: as symbols we are able to give a 'local habitation and a name' to the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: infinite and inconceivable.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Thus we see that no line can be drawn between the powers of sense and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of reflection--they pass imperceptibly into one another. We may indeed
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: distinguish between the seeing and the closed eye--between the sensation
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and the recollection of it. But this distinction carries us a very
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: little way, for recollection is present in sight as well as sight
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: in recollection. There is no impression of sense which does not
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: simultaneously recall differences of form, number, colour, and the like.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Neither is such a distinction applicable at all to our internal bodily
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: sensations, which give no sign of themselves when unaccompanied with
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: pain, and even when we are most conscious of them, have often no
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: assignable place in the human frame. Who can divide the nerves or great
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: nervous centres from the mind which uses them? Who can separate the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: pains and pleasures of the mind from the pains and pleasures of the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: body? The words 'inward and outward,' 'active and passive,' 'mind and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: body,' are best conceived by us as differences of degree passing into
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: differences of kind, and at one time and under one aspect acting in
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: harmony and then again opposed. They introduce a system and order into
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the knowledge of our being; and yet, like many other general terms, are
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: often in advance of our actual analysis or observation.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: According to some writers the inward sense is only the fading away or
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: imperfect realization of the outward. But this leaves out of sight one
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: half of the phenomenon. For the mind is not only withdrawn from
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the world of sense but introduced to a higher world of thought and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: reflection, in which, like the outward sense, she is trained and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: educated. By use the outward sense becomes keener and more intense,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: especially when confined within narrow limits. The savage with little
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: or no thought has a quicker discernment of the track than the civilised
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: man; in like manner the dog, having the help of scent as well as of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: sight, is superior to the savage. By use again the inward thought
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: becomes more defined and distinct; what was at first an effort is made

text: 1. The senses are not merely 'holes set in a wooden horse' (Theaet.),
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: but instruments of the mind with which they are organically connected.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: There is no use of them without some use of words--some natural or
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: latent logic--some previous experience or observation. Sensation, like
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: all other mental processes, is complex and relative, though apparently
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: simple. The senses mutually confirm and support one another; it is hard
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: to say how much our impressions of hearing may be affected by those
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: reasonings. The most cursory glance at objects enables the experienced
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: eye to judge approximately of their relations and distance, although
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: nothing is impressed upon the retina except colour, including gradations
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

text: neighbourhood, although the actual impression made on the eye is very
title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: observation. There is nor the consideration. The greater or less strain
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: upon the nerves of the eye or ear is communicated to the mind and
title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: but of two, which give us a wider range, and help us to discern, by the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: which has given rise to many conjectures. More important than the
title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of sight or of any other sense, of the great complexity of the causes
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

text: 2. The second question, namely, that concerning the relation of the mind
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: to external objects, is really a trifling one, though it has been made
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the subject of a famous philosophy. We may if we like, with Berkeley,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: in the first intoxication of a great thought. But he soon finds that
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: word. He had once hoped that by getting rid of the solidity of matter he
title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: fancies; he has neither more nor less evidence of the supernatural than
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: he had before. He himself has become unsettled, but the laws of the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: world remain fixed as at the beginning. He has discovered that his
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: idealism. The philosophy of Berkeley, while giving unbounded license to
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the imagination, is still grovelling on the level of sense.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: We may, if we please, carry this scepticism a step further, and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: themselves. We may say with Protagoras and Hume that what is appears,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and that what appears appears only to individuals, and to the same
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: individual only at one instant. But then, as Plato asks,--and we must
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

text: The attractiveness of such speculations arises out of their true nature
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

text: philosophy.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: We are often told that we should enquire into all things before we
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: accept them;--with what limitations is this true? For we cannot use
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: our senses without admitting that we have them, or think without
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: principle of knowledge is prior to experience. The truth seems to be
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: we seek to describe this as well as we can. We eat before we know the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: nature of digestion; we think before we know the nature of reflection.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: As our knowledge increases, our perception of the mind enlarges also. We
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: cannot indeed get beyond facts, but neither can we draw any line which
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: separates facts from ideas. And the mind is not something separate
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: from them but included in them, and they in the mind, both having a
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: mind to a succession of feelings and sensations is like the attempt to
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: view a wide prospect by inches through a microscope, or to calculate a
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: happiness or good to pleasure. The different virtues--the various

author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

author: Plato

author: Plato

text: opinions of the world.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Imagination has been called that 'busy faculty' which is always

author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

author: Plato
