text: science, has called attention to many facts and corrected many errors,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: which without it would have been unexamined. Yet it is also itself
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: very liable to illusion. The evidence on which it rests is vague and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: indefinite. The field of consciousness is never seen by us as a whole,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: but only at particular points, which are always changing. The veil
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of language intercepts facts. Hence it is desirable that in making an
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: approach to the study we should consider at the outset what are the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: kinds of error which most easily affect it, and note the differences
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: which separate it from other branches of knowledge.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: a. First, we observe the mind by the mind. It would seem therefore that
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: we are always in danger of leaving out the half of that which is the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: subject of our enquiry. We come at once upon the difficulty of what is
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the meaning of the word. Does it differ as subject and object in the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: same manner? Can we suppose one set of feelings or one part of the mind
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: to interpret another? Is the introspecting thought the same with the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: thought which is introspected? Has the mind the power of surveying its
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: whole domain at one and the same time?--No more than the eye can take in
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the whole human body at a glance. Yet there may be a glimpse round the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: corner, or a thought transferred in a moment from one point of view to
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: another, which enables us to see nearly the whole, if not at once,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: at any rate in succession. Such glimpses will hardly enable us to
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: contemplate from within the mind in its true proportions. Hence the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: firmer ground of Psychology is not the consciousness of inward feelings
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: but the observation of external actions, being the actions not only of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: ourselves, but of the innumerable persons whom we come across in life.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: b. The error of supposing partial or occasional explanation of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: mental phenomena to be the only or complete ones. For example, we are
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: disinclined to admit of the spontaneity or discontinuity of the mind--it
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: seems to us like an effect without a cause, and therefore we suppose the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: train of our thoughts to be always called up by association. Yet it is
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: probable, or indeed certain, that of many mental phenomena there are no
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: mental antecedents, but only bodily ones.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: c. The false influence of language. We are apt to suppose that when
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: there are two or more words describing faculties or processes of the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: mind, there are real differences corresponding to them. But this is not
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the case. Nor can we determine how far they do or do not exist, or
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: by what degree or kind of difference they are distinguished. The same
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: remark may be made about figures of speech. They fill up the vacancy of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: knowledge; they are to the mind what too much colour is to the eye; but
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the truth is rather concealed than revealed by them.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: d. The uncertain meaning of terms, such as Consciousness, Conscience,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Will, Law, Knowledge, Internal and External Sense; these, in the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: language of Plato, 'we shamelessly use, without ever having taken the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: pains to analyze them.'
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: e. A science such as Psychology is not merely an hypothesis, but
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: an hypothesis which, unlike the hypotheses of Physics, can never be
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: verified. It rests only on the general impressions of mankind, and there
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: is little or no hope of adding in any considerable degree to our stock
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of mental facts.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: f. The parallelism of the Physical Sciences, which leads us to analyze
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the mind on the analogy of the body, and so to reduce mental operations
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: to the level of bodily ones, or to confound one with the other.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: g. That the progress of Physiology may throw a new light on Psychology
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: is a dream in which scientific men are always tempted to indulge. But
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: however certain we may be of the connexion between mind and body, the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: explanation of the one by the other is a hidden place of nature which
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: has hitherto been investigated with little or no success.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: h. The impossibility of distinguishing between mind and body. Neither
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: in thought nor in experience can we separate them. They seem to act
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: together; yet we feel that we are sometimes under the dominion of the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: one, sometimes of the other, and sometimes, both in the common use of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: language and in fact, they transform themselves, the one into the good
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: principle, the other into the evil principle; and then again the 'I'
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: comes in and mediates between them. It is also difficult to distinguish
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: outward facts from the ideas of them in the mind, or to separate the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: external stimulus to a sensation from the activity of the organ, or this
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: from the invisible agencies by which it reaches the mind, or any process
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of sense from its mental antecedent, or any mental energy from its
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: nervous expression.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: i. The fact that mental divisions tend to run into one another, and that
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: in speaking of the mind we cannot always distinguish differences of kind
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: from differences of degree; nor have we any measure of the strength and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: intensity of our ideas or feelings.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: j. Although heredity has been always known to the ancients as well as
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: ourselves to exercise a considerable influence on human character, yet
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: we are unable to calculate what proportion this birth-influence bears to
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: nurture and education. But this is the real question. We cannot pursue
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the mind into embryology: we can only trace how, after birth, it begins
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: to grow. But how much is due to the soil, how much to the original
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: latent seed, it is impossible to distinguish. And because we are certain
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: that heredity exercises a considerable, but undefined influence, we must
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: not increase the wonder by exaggerating it.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: k. The love of system is always tending to prevail over the historical
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: investigation of the mind, which is our chief means of knowing it. It
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: equally tends to hinder the other great source of our knowledge of the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: mind, the observation of its workings and processes which we can make
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: for ourselves.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: l. The mind, when studied through the individual, is apt to be
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: isolated--this is due to the very form of the enquiry; whereas, in
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: truth, it is indistinguishable from circumstances, the very language
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: which it uses being the result of the instincts of long-forgotten
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: generations, and every word which a man utters being the answer to some
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: other word spoken or suggested by somebody else.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: III. The tendency of the preceding remarks has been to show that
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Psychology is necessarily a fragment, and is not and cannot be a
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: connected system. We cannot define or limit the mind, but we can
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: describe it. We can collect information about it; we can enumerate the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: principal subjects which are included in the study of it. Thus we are
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: able to rehabilitate Psychology to some extent, not as a branch of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: science, but as a collection of facts bearing on human life, as a
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: part of the history of philosophy, as an aspect of Metaphysic. It is a
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: fragment of a science only, which in all probability can never make any
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: great progress or attain to much clearness or exactness. It is however
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: a kind of knowledge which has a great interest for us and is always
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: present to us, and of which we carry about the materials in our own
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: bosoms. We can observe our minds and we can experiment upon them, and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the knowledge thus acquired is not easily forgotten, and is a help to us
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: in study as well as in conduct.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: The principal subjects of Psychology may be summed up as follows:--
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: a. The relation of man to the world around him,--in what sense and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: within what limits can he withdraw from its laws or assert himself
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: against them (Freedom and Necessity), and what is that which we suppose
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: to be thus independent and which we call ourselves? How does the inward
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: differ from the outward and what is the relation between them, and where
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: do we draw the line by which we separate mind from matter, the soul
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: from the body? Is the mind active or passive, or partly both? Are its
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: movements identical with those of the body, or only preconcerted and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: coincident with them, or is one simply an aspect of the other?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: b. What are we to think of time and space? Time seems to have a nearer
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: connexion with the mind, space with the body; yet time, as well as
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: space, is necessary to our idea of either. We see also that they have
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: an analogy with one another, and that in Mathematics they often
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: interpenetrate. Space or place has been said by Kant to be the form of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the outward, time of the inward sense. He regards them as parts or
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: forms of the mind. But this is an unfortunate and inexpressive way of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: describing their relation to us. For of all the phenomena present to the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: human mind they seem to have most the character of objective existence.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: There is no use in asking what is beyond or behind them; we cannot get
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: rid of them. And to throw the laws of external nature which to us are
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the type of the immutable into the subjective side of the antithesis
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: seems to be equally inappropriate.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: c. When in imagination we enter into the closet of the mind and withdraw
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: ourselves from the external world, we seem to find there more or less
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: distinct processes which may be described by the words, 'I perceive,' 'I
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: feel,' 'I think,' 'I want,' 'I wish,' 'I like,' 'I dislike,' 'I fear,'
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: 'I know,' 'I remember,' 'I imagine,' 'I dream,' 'I act,' 'I endeavour,'
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: 'I hope.' These processes would seem to have the same notions attached
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: to them in the minds of all educated persons. They are distinguished
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: from one another in thought, but they intermingle. It is possible to
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: reflect upon them or to become conscious of them in a greater or less
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: degree, or with a greater or less continuity or attention, and thus
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: arise the intermittent phenomena of consciousness or self-consciousness.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: The use of all of them is possible to us at all times; and therefore
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: in any operation of the mind the whole are latent. But we are able to
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: characterise them sufficiently by that part of the complex action which
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: is the most prominent. We have no difficulty in distinguishing an act
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of sight or an act of will from an act of thought, although thought is
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: present in both of them. Hence the conception of different faculties or
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: different virtues is precarious, because each of them is passing into
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the other, and they are all one in the mind itself; they appear and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: reappear, and may all be regarded as the ever-varying phases or aspects
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: or differences of the same mind or person.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: d. Nearest the sense in the scale of the intellectual faculties
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: is memory, which is a mode rather than a faculty of the mind, and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: accompanies all mental operations. There are two principal kinds of it,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: recollection and recognition,--recollection in which forgotten things
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: are recalled or return to the mind, recognition in which the mind finds
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: itself again among things once familiar. The simplest way in which we
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: can represent the former to ourselves is by shutting our eyes and trying
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: to recall in what we term the mind's eye the picture of the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: surrounding scene, or by laying down the book which we are reading and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: recapitulating what we can remember of it. But many times more powerful
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: than recollection is recognition, perhaps because it is more assisted by
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: association. We have known and forgotten, and after a long interval the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: thing which we have seen once is seen again by us, but with a different
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: feeling, and comes back to us, not as new knowledge, but as a thing to
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: which we ourselves impart a notion already present to us; in Plato's
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: words, we set the stamp upon the wax. Every one is aware of the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: difference between the first and second sight of a place, between a
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: scene clothed with associations or bare and divested of them. We say to
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: ourselves on revisiting a spot after a long interval: How many things
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: have happened since I last saw this! There is probably no impression
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: ever received by us of which we can venture to say that the vestiges are
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: altogether lost, or that we might not, under some circumstances, recover
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: it. A long-forgotten knowledge may be easily renewed and therefore is
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: very different from ignorance. Of the language learnt in childhood not
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: a word may be remembered, and yet, when a new beginning is made, the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: old habit soon returns, the neglected organs come back into use, and the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: river of speech finds out the dried-up channel.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: e. 'Consciousness' is the most treacherous word which is employed in
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the study of the mind, for it is used in many senses, and has rarely,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: if ever, been minutely analyzed. Like memory, it accompanies all mental
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: operations, but not always continuously, and it exists in various
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: degrees. It may be imperceptible or hardly perceptible: it may be the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: living sense that our thoughts, actions, sufferings, are our own. It
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: is a kind of attention which we pay to ourselves, and is intermittent
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: rather than continuous. Its sphere has been exaggerated. It is sometimes
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: said to assure us of our freedom; but this is an illusion: as there
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: may be a real freedom without consciousness of it, so there may be a
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: consciousness of freedom without the reality. It may be regarded as a
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: higher degree of knowledge when we not only know but know that we know.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Consciousness is opposed to habit, inattention, sleep, death. It may be
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: illustrated by its derivative conscience, which speaks to men, not only
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of right and wrong in the abstract, but of right and wrong actions in
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: reference to themselves and their circumstances.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: f. Association is another of the ever-present phenomena of the human
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: mind. We speak of the laws of association, but this is an expression
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: which is confusing, for the phenomenon itself is of the most capricious
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and uncertain sort. It may be briefly described as follows. The simplest
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: case of association is that of sense. When we see or hear separately
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: one of two things, which we have previously seen or heard together, the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: occurrence of the one has a tendency to suggest the other. So the sight
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: or name of a house may recall to our minds the memory of those who once
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: lived there. Like may recall like and everything its opposite. The parts
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of a whole, the terms of a series, objects lying near, words having
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: a customary order stick together in the mind. A word may bring back a
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: passage of poetry or a whole system of philosophy; from one end of the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: world or from one pole of knowledge we may travel to the other in an
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: indivisible instant. The long train of association by which we pass from
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: one point to the other, involving every sort of complex relation, so
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: sudden, so accidental, is one of the greatest wonders of mind...This
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: process however is not always continuous, but often intermittent: we can
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: think of things in isolation as well as in association; we do not mean
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: that they must all hang from one another. We can begin again after an
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: interval of rest or vacancy, as a new train of thought suddenly arises,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: as, for example, when we wake of a morning or after violent exercise.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Time, place, the same colour or sound or smell or taste, will often
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: call up some thought or recollection either accidentally or naturally
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: associated with them. But it is equally noticeable that the new thought
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: may occur to us, we cannot tell how or why, by the spontaneous action of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the mind itself or by the latent influence of the body. Both science and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: poetry are made up of associations or recollections, but we must observe
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: also that the mind is not wholly dependent on them, having also the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: power of origination.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: There are other processes of the mind which it is good for us to study
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: when we are at home and by ourselves,--the manner in which thought
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: passes into act, the conflict of passion and reason in many stages, the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: transition from sensuality to love or sentiment and from earthly love to
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: heavenly, the slow and silent influence of habit, which little by little
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: changes the nature of men, the sudden change of the old nature of man
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: into a new one, wrought by shame or by some other overwhelming impulse.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: These are the greater phenomena of mind, and he who has thought of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: them for himself will live and move in a better-ordered world, and will
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: himself be a better-ordered man.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: At the other end of the 'globus intellectualis,' nearest, not to earth
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and sense, but to heaven and God, is the personality of man, by which
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: he holds communion with the unseen world. Somehow, he knows not how,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: somewhere, he knows not where, under this higher aspect of his being he
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: grasps the ideas of God, freedom and immortality; he sees the forms of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: truth, holiness and love, and is satisfied with them. No account of the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: mind can be complete which does not admit the reality or the possibility
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of another life. Whether regarded as an ideal or as a fact, the highest
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: part of man's nature and that in which it seems most nearly to approach
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the divine, is a phenomenon which exists, and must therefore be included
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: within the domain of Psychology.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: IV. We admit that there is no perfect or ideal Psychology. It is not a
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: whole in the same sense in which Chemistry, Physiology, or Mathematics
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: are wholes: that is to say, it is not a connected unity of knowledge.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Compared with the wealth of other sciences, it rests upon a small number
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of facts; and when we go beyond these, we fall into conjectures and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: verbal discussions. The facts themselves are disjointed; the causes of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: them run up into other sciences, and we have no means of tracing
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: them from one to the other. Yet it may be true of this, as of other
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: beginnings of knowledge, that the attempt to put them together has
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: tested the truth of them, and given a stimulus to the enquiry into them.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Psychology should be natural, not technical. It should take the form
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: which is the most intelligible to the common understanding, because it
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: has to do with common things, which are familiar to us all. It should
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: aim at no more than every reflecting man knows or can easily verify for
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: himself. When simple and unpretentious, it is least obscured by words,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: least liable to fall under the influence of Physiology or Metaphysic.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: It should argue, not from exceptional, but from ordinary phenomena. It
title: Theaetetus

author: Plato

text: question. You mean, if I am not mistaken, something like what occurred
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: to me and to my friend here, your namesake Socrates, in a recent
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: discussion.
title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: as the roots of three or five, showing that they are incommensurable by
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the unit: he selected other examples up to seventeen--there he stopped.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Now as there are innumerable roots, the notion occurred to us of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: attempting to include them all under one name or class.

author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And did you find such a class?
title: Theaetetus

author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Let me hear.

author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: We divided all numbers into two classes: those which are
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: made up of equal factors multiplying into one another, which we compared
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: to square figures and called square or equilateral numbers;--that was
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: one class.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Very good.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: The intermediate numbers, such as three and five, and every
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: other number which is made up of unequal factors, either of a greater
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: multiplied by a less, or of a less multiplied by a greater, and when
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: regarded as a figure, is contained in unequal sides;--all these we
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: compared to oblong figures, and called them oblong numbers.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Capital; and what followed?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: The lines, or sides, which have for their squares the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: equilateral plane numbers, were called by us lengths or magnitudes; and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the lines which are the roots of (or whose squares are equal to) the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: oblong numbers, were called powers or roots; the reason of this latter
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: name being, that they are commensurable with the former [i.e., with the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: so-called lengths or magnitudes] not in linear measurement, but in the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: value of the superficial content of their squares; and the same about
title: Theaetetus

text: solids.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of Theodorus, and that he will not be found guilty of false witness.

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: about knowledge, which is what you appear to want; and therefore
title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: praise be any the less true?

author: Plato

author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: matter, as just now said? Is it not one which would task the powers of

author: Plato

text: men perfect in every way?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: mistaken about you, but do your best to ascertain the true nature of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: knowledge, as well as of other things.

author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: class, try and bring the many sorts of knowledge under one definition.

author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: when the report of questions asked by you was brought to me; but I can
title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

author: Plato

text: something within you which you are bringing to the birth.

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: And like the midwives, I am barren, and the reproach which is often
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

author: Plato

text: to be a midwife, but does not allow me to bring forth. And therefore
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

text: the invention or birth of my own soul, but those who converse with me

author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: astonishing progress; and this in the opinion of others as well as in

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the many fine discoveries to which they cling are of their own making.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: is one of them, and there are many others. The truants often return to

author: Plato

author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: sages. I tell you this long story, friend Theaetetus, because I suspect,

author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: some conception. Come then to me, who am a midwife's son and myself a

author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

text: with Protagoras. Here arises a new question, Theodorus, which threatens
title: Theaetetus

text: to be more serious than the last.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEODORUS: Well, Socrates, we have plenty of leisure.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: That is true, and your remark recalls to my mind an
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: observation which I have often made, that those who have passed their
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: days in the pursuit of philosophy are ridiculously at fault when they
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: have to appear and speak in court. How natural is this!
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEODORUS: What do you mean?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: I mean to say, that those who have been trained in philosophy
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and liberal pursuits are as unlike those who from their youth upwards
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: have been knocking about in the courts and such places, as a freeman is
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: in breeding unlike a slave.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEODORUS: In what is the difference seen?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: In the leisure spoken of by you, which a freeman can always
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: command: he has his talk out in peace, and, like ourselves, he wanders
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: at will from one subject to another, and from a second to a third,--if
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the fancy takes him, he begins again, as we are doing now, caring not
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: whether his words are many or few; his only aim is to attain the truth.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: But the lawyer is always in a hurry; there is the water of the clepsydra
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: driving him on, and not allowing him to expatiate at will: and there is
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: his adversary standing over him, enforcing his rights; the indictment,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: which in their phraseology is termed the affidavit, is recited at
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the time: and from this he must not deviate. He is a servant, and is
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: continually disputing about a fellow-servant before his master, who is
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: seated, and has the cause in his hands; the trial is never about some
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: indifferent matter, but always concerns himself; and often the race
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: is for his life. The consequence has been, that he has become keen and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: shrewd; he has learned how to flatter his master in word and indulge him
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: in deed; but his soul is small and unrighteous. His condition, which has
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: been that of a slave from his youth upwards, has deprived him of growth
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and uprightness and independence; dangers and fears, which were too
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: much for his truth and honesty, came upon him in early years, when the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: tenderness of youth was unequal to them, and he has been driven into
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: crooked ways; from the first he has practised deception and retaliation,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and has become stunted and warped. And so he has passed out of youth
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: into manhood, having no soundness in him; and is now, as he thinks,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: a master in wisdom. Such is the lawyer, Theodorus. Will you have the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: companion picture of the philosopher, who is of our brotherhood; or
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: shall we return to the argument? Do not let us abuse the freedom of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: digression which we claim.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEODORUS: Nay, Socrates, not until we have finished what we are about;
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: for you truly said that we belong to a brotherhood which is free, and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: are not the servants of the argument; but the argument is our servant,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and must wait our leisure. Who is our judge? Or where is the spectator
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: having any right to censure or control us, as he might the poets?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Then, as this is your wish, I will describe the leaders; for
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: there is no use in talking about the inferior sort. In the first place,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the lords of philosophy have never, from their youth upwards, known
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: their way to the Agora, or the dicastery, or the council, or any other
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: political assembly; they neither see nor hear the laws or decrees,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: as they are called, of the state written or recited; the eagerness of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: political societies in the attainment of offices--clubs, and banquets,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and revels, and singing-maidens,--do not enter even into their dreams.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Whether any event has turned out well or ill in the city, what disgrace
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: may have descended to any one from his ancestors, male or female, are
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: matters of which the philosopher no more knows than he can tell, as they
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: say, how many pints are contained in the ocean. Neither is he conscious
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of his ignorance. For he does not hold aloof in order that he may gain a
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: reputation; but the truth is, that the outer form of him only is in the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: city: his mind, disdaining the littlenesses and nothingnesses of human
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: things, is 'flying all abroad' as Pindar says, measuring earth and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the heaven, interrogating the whole nature of each and all in their
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: entirety, but not condescending to anything which is within reach.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEODORUS: What do you mean, Socrates?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: I will illustrate my meaning, Theodorus, by the jest which the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: he fell into a well as he was looking up at the stars. She said, that he
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: was so eager to know what was going on in heaven, that he could not see
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: what was before his feet. This is a jest which is equally applicable to
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: all philosophers. For the philosopher is wholly unacquainted with his
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: next-door neighbour; he is ignorant, not only of what he is doing, but
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: he hardly knows whether he is a man or an animal; he is searching into
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the essence of man, and busy in enquiring what belongs to such a nature
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: to do or suffer different from any other;--I think that you understand
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: me, Theodorus?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEODORUS: I do, and what you say is true.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And thus, my friend, on every occasion, private as well as
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: public, as I said at first, when he appears in a law-court, or in any
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: place in which he has to speak of things which are at his feet and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: before his eyes, he is the jest, not only of Thracian handmaids but of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the general herd, tumbling into wells and every sort of disaster through
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: his inexperience. His awkwardness is fearful, and gives the impression
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of imbecility. When he is reviled, he has nothing personal to say in
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: answer to the civilities of his adversaries, for he knows no scandals
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of any one, and they do not interest him; and therefore he is laughed at
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: for his sheepishness; and when others are being praised and glorified,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: in the simplicity of his heart he cannot help going into fits of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: tyrant or king eulogized, he fancies that he is listening to the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: praises of some keeper of cattle--a swineherd, or shepherd, or perhaps a
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: cowherd, who is congratulated on the quantity of milk which he squeezes
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: from them; and he remarks that the creature whom they tend, and out of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: whom they squeeze the wealth, is of a less tractable and more insidious
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: nature. Then, again, he observes that the great man is of necessity as
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: ill-mannered and uneducated as any shepherd--for he has no leisure,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and he is surrounded by a wall, which is his mountain-pen. Hearing
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of enormous landed proprietors of ten thousand acres and more, our
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: philosopher deems this to be a trifle, because he has been accustomed to
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: think of the whole earth; and when they sing the praises of family, and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of wealthy ancestors, he thinks that their sentiments only betray a
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: dull and narrow vision in those who utter them, and who are not educated
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: enough to look at the whole, nor to consider that every man has had
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and was such as fortune made him, and he had a fiftieth, and so on? He
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: amuses himself with the notion that they cannot count, and thinks that a
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: little arithmetic would have got rid of their senseless vanity. Now, in
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: all these cases our philosopher is derided by the vulgar, partly because
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: he is thought to despise them, and also because he is ignorant of what
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: is before him, and always at a loss.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEODORUS: That is very true, Socrates.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

title: Theaetetus

text: THEODORUS: If you could only persuade everybody, Socrates, as you do me,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of the truth of your words, there would be more peace and fewer evils
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: among men.

text: SOCRATES: Evils, Theodorus, can never pass away; for there must always
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: remain something which is antagonistic to good. Having no place among
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the gods in heaven, of necessity they hover around the mortal nature,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and this earthly sphere. Wherefore we ought to fly away from earth to
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: heaven as quickly as we can; and to fly away is to become like God,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: as far as this is possible; and to become like him, is to become holy,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: just, and wise. But, O my friend, you cannot easily convince mankind
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: that they should pursue virtue or avoid vice, not merely in order that a
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: my judgment is only a repetition of an old wives' fable. Whereas,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the truth is that God is never in any way unrighteous--he is perfect
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: righteousness; and he of us who is the most righteous is most like him.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Herein is seen the true cleverness of a man, and also his nothingness
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and want of manhood. For to know this is true wisdom and virtue, and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: ignorance of this is manifest folly and vice. All other kinds of wisdom
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: or cleverness, which seem only, such as the wisdom of politicians, or
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the wisdom of the arts, are coarse and vulgar. The unrighteous man, or
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: in the illusion that his roguery is clever; for men glory in their
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

author: Plato

author: Plato

author: Plato

author: Plato

author: Plato

text: be escaped.

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: them, or perceive that in their utter folly and infatuation they are
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: growing like the one and unlike the other, by reason of their evil
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: deeds; and the penalty is, that they lead a life answering to the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: talk of idiots.

author: Plato

text: alone (i.e. not insist that 'one' and 'other' are the same (Both words
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: in Greek are called eteron: compare Parmen.; Euthyd.)). I mean to say,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: that no one thinks the noble to be base, or anything of the kind.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: I will give up the word 'other,' Socrates; and I agree to
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: what you say.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: If a man has both of them in his thoughts, he cannot think
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: that the one of them is the other?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: True.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Neither, if he has one of them only in his mind and not the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: other, can he think that one is the other?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: True; for we should have to suppose that he apprehends that
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: which is not in his thoughts at all.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Then no one who has either both or only one of the two objects
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: in his mind can think that the one is the other. And therefore, he who
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: maintains that false opinion is heterodoxy is talking nonsense; for
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: neither in this, any more than in the previous way, can false opinion
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: exist in us.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: No.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: But if, Theaetetus, this is not admitted, we shall be driven
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: into many absurdities.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: What are they?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: I will not tell you until I have endeavoured to consider the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: matter from every point of view. For I should be ashamed of us if we
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: were driven in our perplexity to admit the absurd consequences of which
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: I speak. But if we find the solution, and get away from them, we may
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: regard them only as the difficulties of others, and the ridicule will
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: not attach to us. On the other hand, if we utterly fail, I suppose that
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: we must be humble, and allow the argument to trample us under foot,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: as the sea-sick passenger is trampled upon by the sailor, and to do
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: anything to us. Listen, then, while I tell you how I hope to find a way
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: out of our difficulty.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Let me hear.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: I think that we were wrong in denying that a man could think
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: what he knew to be what he did not know; and that there is a way in
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: which such a deception is possible.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: You mean to say, as I suspected at the time, that I may know
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Socrates, and at a distance see some one who is unknown to me, and whom
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: I mistake for him--then the deception will occur?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: But has not that position been relinquished by us, because
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: involving the absurdity that we should know and not know the things
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: which we know?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: True.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: not have a favourable issue; but as we are in a great strait, every
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: argument should be turned over and tested. Tell me, then, whether I am
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: right in saying that you may learn a thing which at one time you did not
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: know?

author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Certainly you may.

author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: I would have you imagine, then, that there exists in the mind
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of man a block of wax, which is of different sizes in different men;
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: harder, moister, and having more or less of purity in one than another,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and in some of an intermediate quality.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: I see.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of the Muses; and that when we wish to remember anything which we have
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: seen, or heard, or thought in our own minds, we hold the wax to the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: perceptions and thoughts, and in that material receive the impression of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: them as from the seal of a ring; and that we remember and know what is
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: imprinted as long as the image lasts; but when the image is effaced, or
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: cannot be taken, then we forget and do not know.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Very good.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Now, when a person has this knowledge, and is considering
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: something which he sees or hears, may not false opinion arise in the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: following manner?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: In what manner?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: When he thinks what he knows, sometimes to be what he knows,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and sometimes to be what he does not know. We were wrong before in
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: denying the possibility of this.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: And how would you amend the former statement?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: I should begin by making a list of the impossible cases which
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: must be excluded. (1) No one can think one thing to be another when he
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: does not perceive either of them, but has the memorial or seal of both
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of them in his mind; nor can any mistaking of one thing for another
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: occur, when he only knows one, and does not know, and has no impression
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of the other; nor can he think that one thing which he does not know is
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: another thing which he does not know, or that what he does not know
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: is what he knows; nor (2) that one thing which he perceives is another
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: thing which he perceives, or that something which he perceives is
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: something which he does not perceive; or that something which he does
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: not perceive is something else which he does not perceive; or that
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: something which he does not perceive is something which he perceives;
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: nor again (3) can he think that something which he knows and perceives,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and of which he has the impression coinciding with sense, is something
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: else which he knows and perceives, and of which he has the impression
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: coinciding with sense;--this last case, if possible, is still more
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: inconceivable than the others; nor (4) can he think that something which
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: he knows and perceives, and of which he has the memorial coinciding with
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: sense, is something else which he knows; nor so long as these agree,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: can he think that a thing which he knows and perceives is another thing
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: which he perceives; or that a thing which he does not know and does not
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: perceive, is the same as another thing which he does not know and does
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: not perceive;--nor again, can he suppose that a thing which he does not
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: know and does not perceive is the same as another thing which he does
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: not know; or that a thing which he does not know and does not perceive
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: is another thing which he does not perceive:--All these utterly and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: absolutely exclude the possibility of false opinion. The only cases, if
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: any, which remain, are the following.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: What are they? If you tell me, I may perhaps understand you
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: better; but at present I am unable to follow you.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: A person may think that some things which he knows, or which
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: he perceives and does not know, are some other things which he knows and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: perceives; or that some things which he knows and perceives, are other
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: things which he knows and perceives.

author: Plato

author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of person Theaetetus is, at one time see them, and at another time do
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: not see them, and sometimes I touch them, and at another time not, or
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: at one time I may hear them or perceive them in some other way, and at
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: another time not perceive them, but still I remember them, and know them
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: in my own mind.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: may not perceive sensibly that which he knows.

author: Plato

title: Theaetetus

text: perceived by him and sometimes will be perceived and only perceived?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: nor does he perceive them in any other way; he cannot then by any
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

author: Plato

text: not right?

author: Plato

author: Plato

author: Plato

author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: know to be him whom I do not know.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: True.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: you, I cannot think that one of you whom I do not know is the other whom
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: I do not know. I need not again go over the catalogue of excluded cases,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: in which I cannot form a false opinion about you and Theodorus, either
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: when I know both or when I am in ignorance of both, or when I know one
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and not the other. And the same of perceiving: do you understand me?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: I do.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: The only possibility of erroneous opinion is, when knowing you
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and Theodorus, and having on the waxen block the impression of both of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: you given as by a seal, but seeing you imperfectly and at a distance,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: I try to assign the right impression of memory to the right visual
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: impression, and to fit this into its own print: if I succeed,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: recognition will take place; but if I fail and transpose them, putting
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the foot into the wrong shoe--that is to say, putting the vision of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: either of you on to the wrong impression, or if my mind, like the sight
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: in a mirror, which is transferred from right to left, err by reason of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: some similar affection, then 'heterodoxy' and false opinion ensues.

author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: wonderful exactness.

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: know one of you, but not the other, and my knowledge of him does not
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: accord with perception--that was the case put by me just now which you
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: did not understand.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: you, his knowledge coincides with his perception, he will never think
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: him to be some other person, whom he knows and perceives, and the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: knowledge of whom coincides with his perception--for that also was a
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: case supposed.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: True.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: But there was an omission of the further case, in which, as
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: we now say, false opinion may arise, when knowing both, and seeing, or
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: having some other sensible perception of both, I fail in holding the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: seal over against the corresponding sensation; like a bad archer, I miss
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and fall wide of the mark--and this is called falsehood.

author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: When, therefore, perception is present to one of the seals
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: or impressions but not to the other, and the mind fits the seal of the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: absent perception on the one which is present, in any case of this sort
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: perceived, but only in things which are known and perceived; in these
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: alone opinion turns and twists about, and becomes alternately true and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: false;--true when the seals and impressions of sense meet straight and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: opposite--false when they go awry and crooked.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: And is not that, Socrates, nobly said?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Nobly! yes; but wait a little and hear the explanation, and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: then you will say so with more reason; for to think truly is noble and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: to be deceived is base.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Undoubtedly.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And the origin of truth and error is as follows:--When the wax
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: in the soul of any one is deep and abundant, and smooth and perfectly
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: tempered, then the impressions which pass through the senses and sink
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: into the heart of the soul, as Homer says in a parable, meaning to
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: indicate the likeness of the soul to wax (Kerh Kerhos); these, I say,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: being pure and clear, and having a sufficient depth of wax, are also
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: lasting, and minds, such as these, easily learn and easily retain,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and are not liable to confusion, but have true thoughts, for they have
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: plenty of room, and having clear impressions of things, as we term them,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: quickly distribute them into their proper places on the block. And such
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: men are called wise. Do you agree?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Entirely.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: But when the heart of any one is shaggy--a quality which the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: all-wise poet commends, or muddy and of impure wax, or very soft, or
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: very hard, then there is a corresponding defect in the mind--the soft
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: are good at learning, but apt to forget; and the hard are the reverse;
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the shaggy and rugged and gritty, or those who have an admixture of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: earth or dung in their composition, have the impressions indistinct,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: as also the hard, for there is no depth in them; and the soft too are
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: indistinct, for their impressions are easily confused and effaced. Yet
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: greater is the indistinctness when they are all jostled together in a
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: opinion; for when they see or hear or think of anything, they are
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: slow in assigning the right objects to the right impressions--in their
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

author: Plato

author: Plato

text: objects, and ignorant.
