author: Plato

text: elements can be defined; they can only be named, for they have nothing
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: but a name, and the things which are compounded of them, as they are
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: complex, are expressed by a combination of names, for the combination
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of names is the essence of a definition. Thus, then, the elements or
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: letters are only objects of perception, and cannot be defined or known;
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: but the syllables or combinations of them are known and expressed, and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: are apprehended by true opinion. When, therefore, any one forms the true
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: opinion of anything without rational explanation, you may say that his
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: mind is truly exercised, but has no knowledge; for he who cannot give
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and receive a reason for a thing, has no knowledge of that thing; but
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: when he adds rational explanation, then, he is perfected in knowledge
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and may be all that I have been denying of him. Was that the form in
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: which the dream appeared to you?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Precisely.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And you allow and maintain that true opinion, combined with
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: definition or rational explanation, is knowledge?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Exactly.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Then may we assume, Theaetetus, that to-day, and in this
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: casual manner, we have found a truth which in former times many wise men
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: have grown old and have not found?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: At any rate, Socrates, I am satisfied with the present
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: statement.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Which is probably correct--for how can there be knowledge
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: apart from definition and true opinion? And yet there is one point in
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: what has been said which does not quite satisfy me.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: What was it?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: What might seem to be the most ingenious notion of all:--That
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the elements or letters are unknown, but the combination or syllables
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: known.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: And was that wrong?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: We shall soon know; for we have as hostages the instances
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: which the author of the argument himself used.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: What hostages?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: The letters, which are the clements; and the syllables, which
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: are the combinations;--he reasoned, did he not, from the letters of the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: alphabet?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Yes; he did.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Let us take them and put them to the test, or rather, test
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: ourselves:--What was the way in which we learned letters? and, first of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: all, are we right in saying that syllables have a definition, but that
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: letters have no definition?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: I think so.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: I think so too; for, suppose that some one asks you to spell
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the first syllable of my name:--Theaetetus, he says, what is SO?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: I should reply S and O.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: That is the definition which you would give of the syllable?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: I should.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: I wish that you would give me a similar definition of the S.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: But how can any one, Socrates, tell the elements of an
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: element? I can only reply, that S is a consonant, a mere noise, as
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of the tongue hissing; B, and most other letters, again, are neither
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: vowel-sounds nor noises. Thus letters may be most truly said to be
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: undefined; for even the most distinct of them, which are the seven
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: vowels, have a sound only, but no definition at all.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Then, I suppose, my friend, that we have been so far right in
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: our idea about knowledge?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Yes; I think that we have.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Well, but have we been right in maintaining that the syllables
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: can be known, but not the letters?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: I think so.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And do we mean by a syllable two letters, or if there are
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: more, all of them, or a single idea which arises out of the combination
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of them?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: I should say that we mean all the letters.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Take the case of the two letters S and O, which form the first
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: syllable of my own name; must not he who knows the syllable, know both
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of them?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Certainly.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: He knows, that is, the S and O?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Yes.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: But can he be ignorant of either singly and yet know both
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: together?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Such a supposition, Socrates, is monstrous and unmeaning.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: But if he cannot know both without knowing each, then if he is
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: ever to know the syllable, he must know the letters first; and thus the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: fine theory has again taken wings and departed.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Yes, with wonderful celerity.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Yes, we did not keep watch properly. Perhaps we ought to have
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: maintained that a syllable is not the letters, but rather one single
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: idea framed out of them, having a separate form distinct from them.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Very true; and a more likely notion than the other.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Take care; let us not be cowards and betray a great and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: imposing theory.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: No, indeed.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Let us assume then, as we now say, that the syllable is
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: a simple form arising out of the several combinations of harmonious
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: elements--of letters or of any other elements.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Very good.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And it must have no parts.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Why?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Because that which has parts must be a whole of all the parts.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Or would you say that a whole, although formed out of the parts, is a
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: single notion different from all the parts?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: I should.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And would you say that all and the whole are the same, or
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: different?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: I am not certain; but, as you like me to answer at once, I
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: shall hazard the reply, that they are different.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: I approve of your readiness, Theaetetus, but I must take time
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: to think whether I equally approve of your answer.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Yes; the answer is the point.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: According to this new view, the whole is supposed to differ
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: from all?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Yes.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Well, but is there any difference between all (in the plural)
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and the all (in the singular)? Take the case of number:--When we say
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: one, two, three, four, five, six; or when we say twice three, or three
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: times two, or four and two, or three and two and one, are we speaking of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the same or of different numbers?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Of the same.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: That is of six?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Yes.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And in each form of expression we spoke of all the six?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: True.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Again, in speaking of all (in the plural) is there not one
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: thing which we express?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Of course there is.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And that is six?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Yes.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Then in predicating the word 'all' of things measured by
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: number, we predicate at the same time a singular and a plural?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Clearly we do.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Again, the number of the acre and the acre are the same; are
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: they not?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Yes.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And the number of the stadium in like manner is the stadium?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Yes.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And the army is the number of the army; and in all similar
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: cases, the entire number of anything is the entire thing?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: True.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And the number of each is the parts of each?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Exactly.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Then as many things as have parts are made up of parts?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Clearly.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: But all the parts are admitted to be the all, if the entire
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: number is the all?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: True.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Then the whole is not made up of parts, for it would be the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: all, if consisting of all the parts?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: That is the inference.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: But is a part a part of anything but the whole?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Yes, of the all.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: You make a valiant defence, Theaetetus. And yet is not the all
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: that of which nothing is wanting?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Certainly.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And is not a whole likewise that from which nothing is absent?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: but that from which anything is absent is neither a whole nor all;--if
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: wanting in anything, both equally lose their entirety of nature.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: I now think that there is no difference between a whole and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: all.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: But were we not saying that when a thing has parts, all the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: parts will be a whole and all?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Certainly.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Then, as I was saying before, must not the alternative be that
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: either the syllable is not the letters, and then the letters are not
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: parts of the syllable, or that the syllable will be the same with the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: letters, and will therefore be equally known with them?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: You are right.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And, in order to avoid this, we suppose it to be different
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: from them?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Yes.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: But if letters are not parts of syllables, can you tell me of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: any other parts of syllables, which are not letters?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: No, indeed, Socrates; for if I admit the existence of parts
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: in a syllable, it would be ridiculous in me to give up letters and seek
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: for other parts.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Quite true, Theaetetus, and therefore, according to our
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: present view, a syllable must surely be some indivisible form?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: True.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: But do you remember, my friend, that only a little while ago
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: we admitted and approved the statement, that of the first elements out
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of which all other things are compounded there could be no definition,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: because each of them when taken by itself is uncompounded; nor can one
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: rightly attribute to them the words 'being' or 'this,' because they
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: are alien and inappropriate words, and for this reason the letters or
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: elements were indefinable and unknown?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: I remember.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And is not this also the reason why they are simple and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: indivisible? I can see no other.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: No other reason can be given.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Then is not the syllable in the same case as the elements or
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: letters, if it has no parts and is one form?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: To be sure.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: If, then, a syllable is a whole, and has many parts or
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: letters, the letters as well as the syllable must be intelligible and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: expressible, since all the parts are acknowledged to be the same as the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: whole?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: True.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: But if it be one and indivisible, then the syllables and the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: letters are alike undefined and unknown, and for the same reason?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: I cannot deny that.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: We cannot, therefore, agree in the opinion of him who says
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: that the syllable can be known and expressed, but not the letters.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Certainly not; if we may trust the argument.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Well, but will you not be equally inclined to disagree with
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: him, when you remember your own experience in learning to read?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: What experience?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Why, that in learning you were kept trying to distinguish the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: separate letters both by the eye and by the ear, in order that, when
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: you heard them spoken or saw them written, you might not be confused by
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: their position.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Very true.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And is the education of the harp-player complete unless he can
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: tell what string answers to a particular note; the notes, as every one
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: would allow, are the elements or letters of music?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Exactly.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Then, if we argue from the letters and syllables which we know
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: to other simples and compounds, we shall say that the letters or simple
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: elements as a class are much more certainly known than the syllables,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and much more indispensable to a perfect knowledge of any subject; and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: if some one says that the syllable is known and the letter unknown,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: we shall consider that either intentionally or unintentionally he is
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: talking nonsense?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Exactly.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And there might be given other proofs of this belief, if I am
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: not mistaken. But do not let us in looking for them lose sight of the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: question before us, which is the meaning of the statement, that right
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: opinion with rational definition or explanation is the most perfect form
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of knowledge.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: We must not.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Well, and what is the meaning of the term 'explanation'? I
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: think that we have a choice of three meanings.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: What are they?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: In the first place, the meaning may be, manifesting one's
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: thought by the voice with verbs and nouns, imaging an opinion in the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: stream which flows from the lips, as in a mirror or water. Does not
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: explanation appear to be of this nature?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Certainly; he who so manifests his thought, is said to
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: explain himself.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And every one who is not born deaf or dumb is able sooner or
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: later to manifest what he thinks of anything; and if so, all those who
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: have a right opinion about anything will also have right explanation;
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: nor will right opinion be anywhere found to exist apart from knowledge.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: True.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Let us not, therefore, hastily charge him who gave this
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: account of knowledge with uttering an unmeaning word; for perhaps he
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: only intended to say, that when a person was asked what was the nature
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of anything, he should be able to answer his questioner by giving the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: elements of the thing.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: As for example, Socrates...?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: As, for example, when Hesiod says that a waggon is made up
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of a hundred planks. Now, neither you nor I could describe all of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: them individually; but if any one asked what is a waggon, we should be
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: content to answer, that a waggon consists of wheels, axle, body, rims,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: yoke.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Certainly.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And our opponent will probably laugh at us, just as he would
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: if we professed to be grammarians and to give a grammatical account of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the name of Theaetetus, and yet could only tell the syllables and not
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the letters of your name--that would be true opinion, and not knowledge;
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: for knowledge, as has been already remarked, is not attained until,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: combined with true opinion, there is an enumeration of the elements out
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of which anything is composed.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Yes.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: In the same general way, we might also have true opinion about
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: a waggon; but he who can describe its essence by an enumeration of the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: hundred planks, adds rational explanation to true opinion, and instead
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of opinion has art and knowledge of the nature of a waggon, in that he
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: attains to the whole through the elements.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: And do you not agree in that view, Socrates?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: If you do, my friend; but I want to know first, whether you
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: admit the resolution of all things into their elements to be a rational
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: explanation of them, and the consideration of them in syllables or
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: larger combinations of them to be irrational--is this your view?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Precisely.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Well, and do you conceive that a man has knowledge of any
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: element who at one time affirms and at another time denies that element
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of something, or thinks that the same thing is composed of different
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: elements at different times?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Assuredly not.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And do you not remember that in your case and in that of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: others this often occurred in the process of learning to read?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: You mean that I mistook the letters and misspelt the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: syllables?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Yes.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: To be sure; I perfectly remember, and I am very far from
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: supposing that they who are in this condition have knowledge.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: When a person at the time of learning writes the name of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Theaetetus, and thinks that he ought to write and does write Th and e;
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: but, again, meaning to write the name of Theododorus, thinks that he
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: ought to write and does write T and e--can we suppose that he knows the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: first syllables of your two names?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: We have already admitted that such a one has not yet
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: attained knowledge.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And in like manner be may enumerate without knowing them the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: second and third and fourth syllables of your name?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: He may.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And in that case, when he knows the order of the letters and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: can write them out correctly, he has right opinion?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Clearly.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: But although we admit that he has right opinion, he will still
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: be without knowledge?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Yes.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And yet he will have explanation, as well as right opinion,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: for he knew the order of the letters when he wrote; and this we admit to
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: be explanation.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: True.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Then, my friend, there is such a thing as right opinion united
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: with definition or explanation, which does not as yet attain to the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: exactness of knowledge.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: It would seem so.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And what we fancied to be a perfect definition of knowledge
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: is a dream only. But perhaps we had better not say so as yet, for were
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: there not three explanations of knowledge, one of which must, as we
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: said, be adopted by him who maintains knowledge to be true opinion
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: combined with rational explanation? And very likely there may be found
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: some one who will not prefer this but the third.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: You are quite right; there is still one remaining. The first
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: was the image or expression of the mind in speech; the second, which has
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: just been mentioned, is a way of reaching the whole by an enumeration of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the elements. But what is the third definition?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: There is, further, the popular notion of telling the mark or
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: sign of difference which distinguishes the thing in question from all
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: others.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Can you give me any example of such a definition?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: As, for example, in the case of the sun, I think that you
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: would be contented with the statement that the sun is the brightest of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the heavenly bodies which revolve about the earth.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Certainly.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Understand why:--the reason is, as I was just now saying, that
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: if you get at the difference and distinguishing characteristic of each
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: thing, then, as many persons affirm, you will get at the definition or
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: explanation of it; but while you lay hold only of the common and not of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the characteristic notion, you will only have the definition of those
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: things to which this common quality belongs.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: I understand you, and your account of definition is in my
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: judgment correct.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: But he, who having right opinion about anything, can find out
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the difference which distinguishes it from other things will know that
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of which before he had only an opinion.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Yes; that is what we are maintaining.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Nevertheless, Theaetetus, on a nearer view, I find myself
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: quite disappointed; the picture, which at a distance was not so bad, has
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: now become altogether unintelligible.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: What do you mean?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: I will endeavour to explain: I will suppose myself to have
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: true opinion of you, and if to this I add your definition, then I have
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: knowledge, but if not, opinion only.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Yes.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: The definition was assumed to be the interpretation of your
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: difference.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: True.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: But when I had only opinion, I had no conception of your
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: distinguishing characteristics.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: I suppose not.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Then I must have conceived of some general or common nature
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: which no more belonged to you than to another.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: True.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Tell me, now--How in that case could I have formed a judgment
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of you any more than of any one else? Suppose that I imagine Theaetetus
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: to be a man who has nose, eyes, and mouth, and every other member
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: complete; how would that enable me to distinguish Theaetetus from
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Theodorus, or from some outer barbarian?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: How could it?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Or if I had further conceived of you, not only as having nose
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and eyes, but as having a snub nose and prominent eyes, should I have
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: any more notion of you than of myself and others who resemble me?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Certainly not.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Surely I can have no conception of Theaetetus until your
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: snub-nosedness has left an impression on my mind different from the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: snub-nosedness of all others whom I have ever seen, and until your other
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: peculiarities have a like distinctness; and so when I meet you to-morrow
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the right opinion will be re-called?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Most true.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Then right opinion implies the perception of differences?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Clearly.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: What, then, shall we say of adding reason or explanation to
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: right opinion? If the meaning is, that we should form an opinion of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the way in which something differs from another thing, the proposal is
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: ridiculous.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: How so?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: We are supposed to acquire a right opinion of the differences
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: which distinguish one thing from another when we have already a right
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: opinion of them, and so we go round and round:--the revolution of the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: scytal, or pestle, or any other rotatory machine, in the same circles,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: is as nothing compared with such a requirement; and we may be truly
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: described as the blind directing the blind; for to add those things
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: which we already have, in order that we may learn what we already think,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: is like a soul utterly benighted.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Tell me; what were you going to say just now, when you asked
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: the question?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: If, my boy, the argument, in speaking of adding the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: definition, had used the word to 'know,' and not merely 'have an
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: opinion' of the difference, this which is the most promising of all the
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: definitions of knowledge would have come to a pretty end, for to know is
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: surely to acquire knowledge.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: True.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And so, when the question is asked, What is knowledge? this
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: fair argument will answer 'Right opinion with knowledge,'--knowledge,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: that is, of difference, for this, as the said argument maintains, is
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: adding the definition.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: That seems to be true.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: But how utterly foolish, when we are asking what is knowledge,
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: that the reply should only be, right opinion with knowledge of
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: difference or of anything! And so, Theaetetus, knowledge is neither
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: sensation nor true opinion, nor yet definition and explanation
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: accompanying and added to true opinion?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: I suppose not.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And are you still in labour and travail, my dear friend, or
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: have you brought all that you have to say about knowledge to the birth?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: I am sure, Socrates, that you have elicited from me a good
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: deal more than ever was in me.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And does not my art show that you have brought forth wind, and
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: that the offspring of your brain are not worth bringing up?
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: THEAETETUS: Very true.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: But if, Theaetetus, you should ever conceive afresh, you will
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: be all the better for the present investigation, and if not, you will be
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: soberer and humbler and gentler to other men, and will be too modest
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: to fancy that you know what you do not know. These are the limits of my
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: art; I can no further go, nor do I know aught of the things which great
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: and famous men know or have known in this or former ages. The office
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: of a midwife I, like my mother, have received from God; she delivered
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: women, I deliver men; but they must be young and noble and fair.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: And now I have to go to the porch of the King Archon, where I am to meet
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: Meletus and his indictment. To-morrow morning, Theodorus, I shall hope
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato

text: to see you again at this place.
title: Theaetetus
author: Plato
